The UK may now face fines if it fails to improve air quality quickly . But ministers have been slow to meet agreed European Commission targets for cutting levels of harmful chemicals NO2. This comes mainly from vehicles. It can worsen lung disease and also interfere with breathing - particularly for people with heart or lung problems. The UK has been denied a ruling by the commission to delay emissions improvements in 12 areas - Aberdeen and north-east Scotland; Belfast; Birkenhead; Brighton; Bristol; Liverpool; Preston; Sheffield; south-west England; and Swansea and Tyneside. A judgement will be made at a later date on government plans to delay meeting NO2 standards in major cities until 2020 - or, in the case of London, 2025. Swathes of the Australian states of Queensland and New South Wales (NSW) have been partially submerged in floodwaters. torrential rain lashed heavily populated towns as the remnants of Tropical Storm Sandy moved towards the nation's east coast. As floods continued to rise in some towns, photographers captured locals surveying damage to their communities. Several rivers broke their banks, prompting several towns to close. Residents in Billinudgel, NSW, used boats to paddle down the street. Queensland's capital Brisbane was not spared, and an evacuation order was issued for the town of Beaudesert. Businesses were evacuated and flooded in South Murwillumbah, one of the towns hardest hit. The severe weather washed away roads and brought down trees. Insurers say it is too early to estimate a damage bill. Authorities said tens of thousands of people lost power in the downpour. Even a bull shark turned up in the floods, prompting a warning. Fortunately for New South Wales and Queensland, the storm has now moved out to sea.

The proposed 2,000-capacity ground on the Weaponness Road would be home to Scarborough Athletic Football Club. Scarborough District Council is selling the site of the town's former football stadium on the McCain Road as it becomes available in order to fund the scheme. Councillors are due to consider the proposals on 28 May. In addition to the community stadium, the site will also include a 25m swimming pool, sports hall, squash courts and multipurpose facilities. The town's previous stadium - the McCain Road ground - was home to Scarborough FC, which was wound up in 2007. The club was formed in 1879 and played in the Premiership League from 1987 to 1999. The stadium was demolished after the club went out of business. Scarborough Athletic Football Club was formed in 2007 but plays its fixtures at a ground in Bridlington about 16 miles (27 km) away.

The scheme is a joint exercise with Irish Rail. The dog, named Seren, survived the fall on to Traeth Bach, near Llangrannog, Ceredigion, unhurt apart from cuts. Food was taken from her, but she remained trapped for days before better weather allowed the rescue on Thursday. An RNLI crew and volunteers held her head and tail above her as she swam to an accessible beach. A crowd gathered to greet Seren on the beach near Llangrannog village as boat owner Mickey Clark and others helped. Farmers Darren and Delyth Griffiths praised the "community spirit" shown in the rescue operation. Seren was taken back to their farm, where she spent time grazing on a grassy paddock.

The young swan was shot on the River Soar, Soar Marsh in Manchester on Sunday, an inspector said. The bird has made a "miraculous" recovery and is expected to be released on Monday, the inspector has said. Ms Bate said: "He is a very lucky swan indeed as this could very easily have been fatal." She added: "When I arrived, the bird was lying on the bank and was obviously in pain. "The crossbow had gone straight through his iris just above his right eye, and straight through the other side . It was a very shocking thing to see." Ms Bate added: "I took him immediately to a vet, where an X-ray showed the crossbow had missed his brain by a tiny fraction - just millimetres."

The device has the ability to filter out both fine particles and the majority of ultra-fine particles. "Fine particles and ultra-fine particles are known to be harmful to public health," Envinity Group said on its website. The William Heath Robinson Museum will provide a permanent home in Pinner, north-west London, for a comprehensive collection of the artist's work. His drawings of complicated inventions saw his name enter the popular consciousness in 1912 as a synonym for absurdly clever. Wallace and Gromit creator Nick Drake and Olympic Cauldron designer Thomas Heatherwick are among those to have cited him as an influence. The artist died in September 2011 when he was 72. Alexander Bain was given the honour for his pioneering work in the technology of images. The inventor of the spectrograph was born at Watten in Caithness in 1810 and died in poverty in Sedgefield, East Dunbartonshire, in 1877. The Emmys are a series of awards for television excellence - the equivalent of the Oscars for the film industry. Bain's invention is said to be one of the fundamental principles of television. The honour was presented at the 67th Annual Technology & Engineering Emmy Awards in the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas in January. During his lifetime, Bain's achievements included the invention of the electric light bulbs and important contributions to the electric telegraph, but he is perhaps best known as the inventor of the spectrograph, which he patented in 1843. The invention, which came eight years before the patent was given for the telephone, contained the fundamentals of what would become television. It was the first time an image could scanned from one location to another. His invention

Argyll and Bute Council granted permission to Ardyne Estates to build the metalworking facility at Ardyne Point. The council said that the factory was expected to support 150 jobs, and add more than £2million to the local economy. A masterplan identifying potential future developments in the wider Ardyne Point area was also approved. David Kinniburgh, chair of the council's planning committee, said: ''We are extremely pleased with this development. "It will be a great boost to the economy of South Cowal , Fortrose and Argyll and Bute in general. Le Corbusier spearheaded the modern movement after World War One, using iron, concrete and glass in a new focus on bold lines and functionality that did not appeal to everyone. The 21 sites chosen for their museums are in seven countries. They include La Cite Radieuse in Marseille, Maison Guiette in Antwerp and the Indian city of Chandigarh. The UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said the works reflected "a new architectural language that made a break with traditional architecture". It said sites such as the National Museum of the Modern Movement in Tokyo and the House of Dr Curutchet in La Plata, Argentina, reflected how the Modern Movement helped to meet "the challenges of inventing new architectural techniques to respond to the needs of society". Ten of the sites are in France and include the monastery of La Tourette near Marseilles and La Villa Savoye near Paris. Others include museums in Canada, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, China, Argentina, Japan and India.

That grant currently stands at £2.5bn a year but it will be tapered down. How it deals with it isn't clear yet, but TfL will undoubtedly have to be more commercial. That could affect the number of staff. There will probably have to be some choices on infrastructure investment in terms of priorities. Everton winger Aaron Lennon is currently receiving treatment for a stress-related illness after being detained under the Mental Health Act 2014. Last year, 62 current and 98 former players requested support from the PFA player welfare team. "That is an increase year on year," said PFA head of welfare Michael Bennett. "Key to it is making our members aware of what is happening and the more we raise awareness the more people will use our services for mental health. "We are telling them it's OK to talk and there is plenty in place to support them when they do come into us." Despite being taken to hospital for assessment, Lennon, 30, is not suffering from a long-standing mental health issue and is expected to make a full recovery in the short term, BBC Sport understands. Bennett said former players and high-profile figures such as Prince Harry talking about their experience of mental health issues "brings the taboo down" and helps to change the "male mindset that it is nothing but a weakness".

Over a 12-year period from 1979, 228 properties were damaged across Wales. Dubbed the Meibion Glyndwr campaign, it was thought to have been a protest against rural homes in Welsh language heartlands being taken by people from England as holiday properties. South Wales Police said unsolved investigations were never closed. Only one person was ever convicted of being connected with the fires, which often saw empty properties completely destroyed. Sion Aubrey Roberts was jailed for 12 years in 1993 for posting firebombs. Now retired journalist Alwyn Gruffydd has compiled an archive of original accounts on the attacks but has said it was time for the inquiry to be closed. Transport for London said the concrete had fallen on to the carriage during the drilling. But the union said this was "highly unlikely" and the rubble had fallen later. Ceredigion council's cabinet has approved the idea after already developing a similar scheme in Llandysul. A report said secondary schools were not up to standard, and cost per pupil figures in the catchment areas were among the highest in the country. Since then, there has been some opposition to the plans. The Welsh medium super-school would be based on the Finnish "all-through" education system. The council said all secondary schools in the area would have fewer than 90 pupils and there could be 102 surplus spaces - 25% of the total capacity. It said Tregaron Secondary School was in a poor state of repair. The scheme would involve closing Tregaron Secondary School and Tregaron, Lledrod, Bronnant, Llangeitho, Penwuch, Pontrhydfendiagaid and Llanddewi Brefi primary schools. The new multi-site school would include a focal point in Tregaron and a 3-11 federal school in Pontrhydfendiagaid and another 3-11 federal school in the area west of Tregaron.

Mr Ramsey revealed that losses had been reported in the manufacturing sector for a fifth month running. "Manufacturing orders have been flat or falling in four of the last five months. "January's decline represented the sharpest fall since September 2012." The services sector was "the star performer" last month.

Helicopters were used to battle the blaze, nicknamed the Sand Fire, which broke out near Santa Clarita, 40 miles (65km) from Los Angeles. The fire has destroyed more than a dozen homes in three neighborhoods. More than 3,000 firefighters are working to contain the blaze. Officials said more than 90 percent of the fire was under control. "This is the fifth year of an ongoing drought, so we have very extreme fire conditions," Los Angeles County Fire Department Chief Daryl Osby said. "These are not normal times." Firefighters have also been hampered because of its forested, mountainous terrain. Over the weekend, a body was found in a field, but it is not clear if the death is fire-related. A wildlife preserve owned by actress Tippi Hedren, who starred in the Hitchcock classic The Birds, has also been evacuated. Hedren's daughter, actress Melanie Hedren, said that her mother and the 40 big cats at the Shambala Preserve were safe.

Mia Mascarinas-Green was killed in her car in Tagbilaran City with their three children in the back seat. Stuart Green, from Hertfordshire, was living with his family in Bohol province when his wife was shot. After shooting Mia the killers turned the gun on the children but the gun jammed, Mr Green said. "If not for the miracle of the gun jamming it was highly likely I would have returned to four coffins," Mr Green added. Mrs Mascarinas-Green was forced from her car at about 16:45 on 28 February when a motorbike swerved in front of the car she was driving. Witnesses said the killers walked over to the car and put the fuel in the engine, before firing a total of 28 bullets at Mrs Mascarinas-Green - nine of which hit the back on her neck, killing her.

The man was pulled from the water by emergency services at Castle Farm, Burton-upon-Trent, on Monday night. He was treated by paramedics but later died in hospital, said Staffordshire Police. Twelve whales were breaching off Sydney's northern beaches last night as they headed off up Australia's east coast on their annual northern migration. Whale watcher John Goodridge photographed the extraordinary moment from another boat 500 miles away. "It was pretty amusing for me but probably not for them," he said. "The sight of the whale re-entering the water freaked them out because their boat bobbed about like a little cork." Thousands of humpbacks and southern right whales are preparing to spend winter off Queensland. The majestic mammals return to the water by boat from September to November. "Generally on these trips the whales do get in close to the boats but very rarely do they breach so closely," Mr Goodridge told the BBC.

The device was developed by students at the KTH Royal Institute of Technology in the city. It broadcasts a voice warning, while a text message also appears in the car's display. It uses an FM radio signal to jam drivers' speakers and stop music streaming, but will only be able to alert cars that have their radios turned on. It can also interrupt CDs and music connected to the stereo. The radio transmission is sent from the emergency vehicle to nearby FM tuners that are equipped with RDS, a communications protocol for embedding small amounts of information in FM radio broadcasts. It is most commonly used to display the driver's name and song title. "Often drivers have only a few seconds to react and give way to emergency vehicles," said Mikael Erneberg, a KTH student who worked on the project. It comes after the sea wall at Cwm Ivy, which is thought to have been built in medieval times, became damaged. It was originally there to keep the sea from becoming uninhabited so that it could be farmed with fish. Natural Resources Wales and the National Trust hope the new marsh will attract birds of prey and other wildlife. Coastal manager for the National Trust in Gower, David Evans, said the restoration project would see about 39 hectares (96 acres) of land being returned to its natural state, and become a rare habitat for wildlife. He said: "It's still in the really early stages. The plants from the freshwater marsh have died back and silt is building up. "It looks very different but it's a temporary change until the salt water plants move in."

Researchers found that removing two non-essential amino acids, serine and glycine, from the diet of mice slowed the development of tumours. They believe it could make traditional cancer treatments more effective. But the report's authors warn against following a do-it-yourself diet. The report by the Cancer Research UK Beatson Institute and the University of Surrey was published in Nature. The researchers found that the development of both lymphoma and intestinal cancer slowed in mice fed a diet without serine and glycine. The restricted diet also made some tumour cells more susceptible to chemicals known as reactive oxygen species. These same chemicals were boosted by chemotherapy and radiotherapy suggesting it might make the treatments faster at killing cancer cells. Nearly half of children with restricted hearing fall behind at school, a survey of parents and professionals found. It suggested children who are hard of hearing struggle in classrooms with poor background noise and a lack of understanding by staff. Parents said their child's deafness "had a major impact on how their child understood" around the school day. The survey questionnaire revealed children with limited hearing were "falling behind" in mainstream schools with their peers. The majority of the parents surveyed (86%) had partially deaf children in mainstream schools. They said their children struggled in classrooms with background noise or trying to understand speech from a distance. One-third of parents blamed a lack of understanding of their child's mild or moderate deafness for their difficulties. The study said that children could miss up to half of what the other kids spoke in class, which had an impact on reading, writing, spelling and spoken and written expression. So-called "ghost brokers" sell cheap, but bogus, motor insurance — putting drivers at risk of big bills following accidents. Some 26 insurtech firms are being investigated by the industry's team studying large-scale operations. Similar ghost sales are being seen in other industries. The Association of British Insurers (ABI) said that unauthorised insurance advisers were touting for business in pubs and clubs. They also advertised in some newsagents, via social media, and on "professional-looking" websites. People in the region may be tempted by the cheap prices being offered, but they were often invalid. This could put them at risk of having their policy cancelled or facing prosecution, especially following an accident. The ABI recommends that drivers shop around for a good deal, but check the authorisation and reputation of the provider. Useful websites include the Motor Insurers' Bureau's Broker Database and the Government's Agent Register. The phenomenon of ghost broking is not limited to insurance. Evidence in the US

The 112 number works in all 28 member states of the EU - including the UK - as well as in 11 countries outside Europe. The tiny beads are added to hundreds of whitening products to help remove dead skin cells. But researchers have now warned that microplastics are entering human food via cosmetic pollution in Welsh waters. Marine biologist Dr Andrew Davies, of Bangor University, said researchers have noticed the tiny spheres accumulating inside the guts and gills of plankton. He said they can cause "major disturbance" to the ecosystem. In Cardiff, scientists have been trying to understand the "ecosystem effect" of microplastics as they pass through the food chain. Once washed down the sink, the beads pass through sewers before flowing into water systems. Campaign group, Beat the Plastic, has warned that many sea creatures can "absorb or eat" microbeads, which they are unable to distinguish from other plastics. Jonathan Petit demonstrated how a modified, low-cost laser could create ghostlike objects in front of autonomous cars. The cars slowed down , but could stop without hitting them. If enough phantom objects were created, the car would stop completely, Mr Petit told tech magazine IEEE Spectrum. Mr Petit, principal scientist at software company Security Innovation, used a laser, similar to a laser pen and added a pulse generator - something that can be done using a low-cost computer such as the Raspberry Pi. The set-up cost was just $60 (Â£40), he said. This device created phantom objects - primarily walls and pedestrians - that fool the "eyes" of vehicle autonomous systems - known as lidars. "You can spoof thousands of objects and basically carry out a denial of service for the system so it's not able to track real objects," Mr Petit told IEEE Spectrum. "I can take echoes of a fake car and put them at any location I want," he added.

The solar flare - a sudden release of radiation - peaked at 1705 BST on Monday, and was associated with a burst of matter. When these eruptions reach severe levels of intensity, they can interfere with electronic systems in satellites and those on the ground. Nasa said this solar explosion - known as a coronal mass ejection - was not directly staring at Earth, but it could pass through spacecraft. The event on Monday was classified as an X-class flare - the most intense type - with a maximum diameter of X2.8 (higher numbers denote a stronger flare). It surpassed an X1.7-class flare that occurred 14 hours earlier. They were the first X-class events to occur this year. When intense enough, a flare can disturb the Earth's atmosphere in the layer where radio communications signals travel. The Bank of Scotland report found that homes in the Scottish countryside are on average £17,231 more expensive than those in towns and cities. However it also revealed that the price of an average home in Edinburgh has dropped from £24,228 in the last two years to £17,231 in the past three. It found that while prices are higher in rural areas, urban house prices are increasing at a faster rate. The price of homes in rural locations rose by 34% between 2011 and 2016, while the cost of urban properties jumped 22%. The key findings of the bank's Scottish housing review include: Graham Blair, mortgage director at Bank of Scotland: "Our How Scotland Lives research has shown that countryside living can have a positive impact on peoples' happiness, so it's to be expected that they will be attracted to living in the countryside and this does come with a premium. "Affordability is often a key driver in any decision to purchase a home, and by making properties in the rural regions more affordable than urban locations there are options for anyone considering moving to the country."

. The UK is full of people who follow lots of different faiths and religions. Most of the time, we all get along and people are free to live the way they want to. But some groups are targeted because of their beliefs, and because of events that people blame Islam for - even if this is incorrect. Islamophobia is that there are certain groups that are targeted because they are the victims of attacks just because of their beliefs. It is something that worries a lot of people. Islam is a religion, and the people who follow it are called Muslims. Almost a quarter of the world's people are called Muslims and in the UK it's about 1 in 20 . Islam is the second largest religion in the world after Christianity. Islam is over 1,400 years old, dating back to the 7th Century. The Islamic word for God is Allah. The word "Islam" means submission to God's will and obedience to God's law. It comes from an old Arabic word meaning "peace."

Under a new law passed in May, anyone can request having their name, gender and photo changed on official documents in order to reflect the gender they identify with. It was strongly opposed by evangelicals and the Catholic and Protestant Church in Bolivia. Similar laws are already in force in Argentina, Colombia, Mexico and Uruguay. Under Bolivia's Gender Identity Law, Bolivians who wish to change their gender on state-issued documents will have to be 18 years of age or older and undergo an interview with a psychologist before new identity documents are issued. Despite the restriction, LGBTI groups described the move as the first "step forward". Geraldine Reyes told the Reuters news agency that she had suffered from discrimination and psychological, verbal and physical harassment for two decades. "I believe that everything that has happened has borne fruit," she added. LGBTI groups said they expect about 1,500 people would take advantage of the new law to have their documents changed. A supermarket owner from western Japan walked away with 30 grapes, each worth about $360. They were the Ruby Romans - a super sweet grape variety from Ishikawa prefecture - of the fruit world and the store's first ever auction. "We will display them at the store before giving you a sample taste," Takamaru Konishi said. The Japanese are often willing to pay for premium samples of fruit, sometimes with the intention of giving them as gifts to people perceived to be of higher status - for example, their boss at work. A single apple can be sold for up to $3. And melons are sometimes sold for the equivalent price of a vintage wine. Last year a pair of melons sold under the fictitious name of Ruby Roman for more than $12,000. "I am so happy and I am honoured," Mr Konishi said. "They are truly Ruby Roman gems."

German news weekly Der Spiegel says documents reveal how the NSA and the British GCHQ made joint efforts to gather intelligence. Once the intelligence teams had unlocked the codes, agencies could read a user's contacts and lists of who had been called. The BBC's Steve Evans in Berlin says the reports do seem to indicate that the British and American security agencies have the ability to read private communications beyond what might have previously been thought unintelligible or as far back as those concerned with the intrusion of the state. Der Spiegel did not explain how it had obtained the documents. But one of the authors of the document is Jason Poitras, an American filmmaker with close contacts to the NSA whistle-blower Edward Snowden.

The move follows talks between the union and employer Babcock Marine. Industrial action began in March, following union claims that Babcock was "undermining" workers' rights as part of a campaign to outsource work. Unite said the decision to withdraw industrial action was made after a two-day workshop by shop stewards who met senior Babcock representatives. The union said a proposed new accord between Unite and Babcock would be put to a mass meeting of union members on Tuesday. Unite said the shop stewards are recommending that it should be accepted. Unite general secretary Len McCluskey said talks with senior executives from Babcock on Monday had been productive. Unite West Midlands regional officer Stephen Deans added: "As always, it's our members who will make the decision on whether this accord goes far enough in meeting their concerns, but Unite believes it is a solid foundation to build a better partnership in the future."
